section.title: Special Symbols [CLHS-1.4.1.3]
section.para:
The final delimiter
final delimiter of an interactive stream: &unix; type &ctrl;D at the beginning of a line &win32; type &ctrl;Z, followed by Return
This final delimiter is never actually seen by programs; no need to test for #\^D or #\^Z - use &read-char-no-hang; to check for &eos;. Calling &clear-input; on the stream removes the &eos; state, thus making it available for further input.
A newline character can be entered by the user by pressing the Newline key or, on the numeric keypad, the Enter key.

section.title: Error Terminology [CLHS-1.4.2]
section.para: Safety settings are ignored by the interpreted code; therefore where the standard uses the phrase should signal an error, an &err-sig;. See for the safety of compiled code.

section.title: Symbols in the Package &cl-pac; [CLHS-1.9]
section.para: All 978 symbols in the &cl-pac; package specified by the &ansi-cl; are implemented.

section.title: Standard Characters [CLHS-2.1.3]
section.para: The standard characters are &nl-s; and the graphic characters with a &code-char; between 32 and 126 (inclusive).

section.title: Reader Algorithm [CLHS-2.2]
section.para: The requirement of step 4 that a reader macro function may return zero values or one value &is-e; enforced. You can use the function &values; to control the number of values returned.

section.title: Symbols as Tokens [CLHS-2.3.4]
section.para:
A reserved token
reserved token, i.e., a token that has potential number syntax but cannot be interpreted as a &number-t;, is interpreted as &symbol-t; when being read.

section.title: Valid Patterns for Tokens [CLHS-2.3.5]
section.para: When a token with package markers is read, then no checking is done whether the package part and the symbol-name part do not have number syntax. (What's the purpose of this check?) So we consider tokens like USER:: or :1 or LISP::4711 or 21:3 as symbols.

section.title: Backquote [CLHS-2.4.6]
section.para:
The backquote read macro also works when nested. Example:
(&eval; ``(,#'(&lambda-m; () ',a) ,#'(&lambda-m; () ',b))) ≡ (&eval; `(list #'(&lambda-m; () ',a) #'(&lambda-m; () ',b))) ≡ (&eval; (list 'list (list 'function (list 'lambda nil (list 'quote a))) (list 'function (list 'lambda nil (list 'quote b)))))

section.title: Sharpsign [CLHS-2.4.8]

chapter.title: Evaluation and Compilation [CLHS-3]
chapter.para: All the functions built by &function;, &compile; and the like are atoms. There are built-in functions written in &c-lang;, compiled functions (both of type &compiled-function-t;) and interpreted functions (of type &function-t;).

formalpara.title: Macro &the-env;
formalpara.para: As in Scheme, the macro (&the-env;) returns the current &lex-env;. This works only in interpreted code and is not compilable!

formalpara.title: Function (EXT:EVAL-ENV &form-r; &optional-amp; &env-r;)
formalpara.para: evaluates a form in a given &lex-env;, just as if the form had been a part of the program that the &env-r; came from.

section.title: Dynamic Variables [CLHS-3.1.2.1.1.2]
section.para: Undefined variables, i.e. &variable;s which are referenced outside any lexical binding for a variable of the same name and which are not declared &special-dec;, are treated like &dyn-var;s in the &glo-env;. The compiler &signal;s a &warning-t; when it encounters an undefined variable.

section.title: Conses as Forms [CLHS-3.1.2.1.2]
section.para: Lists of the form ((&setf; &symbol-r;) ...) are also treated as function forms. This makes the syntax (&funcname-r; &args-r; ...) consistent with the syntax (&funcall; #'&funcname-r; &args-r; ...). It implements the item 7 of the &ansi-cl; issue &iss174; and the definition of function forms, and is consistent with the use of &funname;s elsewhere in &cl;.

section.title: Compiler Terminology [CLHS-3.2.1]
section.para: &clisp; compiles to platform-independent &bytecode;.

section.title: Compiler Macros [CLHS-3.2.2.1]
section.para: Compiler macros are expanded in the compiled code only, and ignored by the interpreter.

section.title: Definition of Similarity [CLHS-3.2.4.2.2]
section.para: Hash tables are &ext-obj;s.

section.title: Declarations [CLHS-3.3]
section.para: The declarations (&type-dec; &type-r; &var-r; ...), (&ftype-dec; &type-r; &func-r; ...), are ignored by both the interpreter and the compiler.

formalpara.title: Declaration ¬spec;
formalpara.para: Declarations (&proclaim; '(&special-dec; &var-r;)) and &defconstant; are undone by the (&proclaim; '(¬spec; &var-r;)) declaration. This declaration can be used only in global &proclaim; and &declaim; forms, not in local &declare; forms. Of course, you cannot expect miracles: functions compiled before the ¬spec; proclamation was issued will still be treating &var-r; as special even after the ¬spec; proclamation.

formalpara.title: Function &spe-var-p;
formalpara.para: You can use the function (&spe-var-p; &symbol-r; &optional-amp; &env-r;) to check whether the symbol is a special variable. &env-r; of &nil; or omitted means use the &glo-env;. You can also obtain the current &lex-env; using the macro &the-env; (interpreted code only). This function will always return &t; for global special variables and &constant;s.

section.title: Declaration &safety-dec;
section.para: Declaration (&optimize-dec; (&safety-dec; 3)) results in safe compiled code: function calls are never eliminated. This guarantees the semantics described in &ansi-cl; Section 3.5.

section.title: Declaration &compile-decl;
section.para:
The declaration &compile-decl; has the effect that the current form is compiled prior to execution. Examples:
(&locally; (&declare; (compile)) &form-r;)
executes a compiled version of &form-r;.

(&let; ((x 0)) (&flet; ((inc () (&declare; (compile)) (&incf; x)) (dec () (&decf; x))) (&values; #'inc #'dec)))
returns two functions. The first is compiled and increments &x-r;, the second is interpreted (slower) and decrements the same &x-r;.
The type assertion (&the; &val-type-r; &form-r;) enforces a type check in interpreted code. No type check is done in compiled code. See also the ðe; macro.

section.title: Boa Lambda Lists [CLHS-3.4.6]
section.para: The initial value of an &aux-amp; variable in a boa &lalist; is the value of the corresponding slot's initial form.

section.title: Function &constantp;
section.para: Function &constantp; fully complies with &ansi-cl;. Additionally, some non-trivial forms are identified as constants, e.g., (&constantp; '(+ 1 2 3)) returns &t;.

section.title: Macro &eval-when;
section.para: &eval-when; also accepts the situations (NOT EVAL) and (NOT COMPILE).

warning.para: The situations EVAL, LOAD and COMPILE are deprecated by the spec, and they are &not-e; equivalent to the new standard situations :EXECUTE, :LOAD-TOPLEVEL and :COMPILE-TOPLEVEL in that they ignore the &top-level-form; versus non-&top-level-form; distinction.

section.title: Type Specifiers [CLHS-4.2.3]
section.para: The general form of the &complex-t; type specifier is (&complex-t; type-of-real-part type-of-imaginary-part). The type specifier (&complex-t; &type-r;) is equivalent to (&complex-t; &type-r; &type-r;).
&deftype; &lalist;s are subject to destructuring (nested &lalist;s are allowed, as in &defmacro;) and may contain a &whole-amp; marker, but not an &environment-amp; marker.

formalpara.para: If typespec is a user-defined type, this will expand it recursively until it is no longer a user-defined type (unless once-p is supplied and non-&nil;). Two values are returned - the expansion and an indicator (&t; or &nil;) of whether the original typespec was a user-defined type.

section.title: Classes [CLHS-4.3]
section.para:
The &clos; symbols are &export;ed from the package &clos-pac;. &cl-pac; uses (as in &use-package;) &clos-pac; and &re-export;s the &ansi-cl; standard exported symbols (the &clisp; extensions, e.g., those described in , are &not-e; &re-export;ed). Since the default &use-k; argument to &make-package; is &cl-pac;, the standard &clos; symbols are normally visible in all user-defined packages. If you do not want them (for example, if you want to use the PCL implementation of &clos; instead of the native one), do the following:
(&defpackage; "CL-NO-CLOS" (:use "CL")) (&do-external-symbols; (&symbol-r; &cl-pac;) (&shadow; &symbol-r; "CL-NO-CLOS")) (&do-symbols; (&symbol-r; "CL-NO-CLOS") (&export; &symbol-r; "CL-NO-CLOS")) (&in-package; "CL-NO-CLOS") (&load; "pcl") ; or whatever (&defpackage; "MY-USER" (:use "CL-NO-CLOS")) (&in-package; "MY-USER") ;; your code which uses PCL goes here .

section.title: Deviations from &ansi-cl;
section.para: &defclass; supports the option &metaclass-k; &structure-class;. This option is necessary in order to define a subclass of a &defstruct;-defined structure type using &defclass; instead of &defstruct;.

When &call-next-method; is called with arguments, the rule that the ordered set of applicable methods must be the same as for the original arguments is enforced by the implementation only in interpreted code.

&gen-flet; GENERIC-FLET and &gen-labels; GENERIC-LABELS
are implemented as macros, not as special operators (as permitted by Section 3.1.2.1.2.2). They are not imported into the packages &clu-pac; and &cl-pac; because of the &ansi-cl; issue &iss181;.
&print-object; is only called on objects of type &standard-object-t; and &structure-object-t;. It is not called on other objects, like &cons-t;es and &number-t;s, due to the performance concerns.

section.title: Standard Metaclasses [CLHS-4.3.1.1]
Defining Classes [CLHS-4.3.2]
section.para: &defclass; supports the &metaclass-k; option. Possible values are &standard-class; (the default), &structure-class; (which creates structure classes, like &defstruct; does), and user-defined meta-classes (see ).

It is &not-e; required that the superclasses of a class are defined before the &defclass; form for the class is evaluated. Use &mop; generic functions &class-finalized-p; to check whether the class has been finalized and thus its instances can be created, and &finalize-inheritance; to force class finalization.

section.title: Redefining Classes [CLHS-4.3.6]
section.para: Trivial changes, e.g., those that can occur when doubly loading the same code, do not require updating the instances. These are the changes that do not modify the set of local slots accessible in instances, e.g., changes to slot options &initform-k;, &documentation-k;, and changes to class options :DEFAULT-INITARGS, &documentation-k;.

The instances are updated when they are first accessed, &not-e; at the time when the class is redefined or &make-instances-obsolete; is called. When the class has been redefined several times since the instance was last accessed, &update-instance-for-redefined-class; is still called just once.

section.title: Function &coerce;
section.para: &fixnum-t; is not a character designator in &ansi-cl;, although &code-char; provides an obvious venue to &coerce; a &fixnum-t; to a &character-t;. When &fixnum-char-ansi; is &nil;, &clisp; &coerce;s &fixnum-t;s to &character-t;s via &code-char;. When &fixnum-char-ansi; is non-&nil;, &fixnum-t;s cannot be &coerce;d to &character-t;s.

section.title: The Data and Control Flow Dictionary [CLHS-5.3]

formalpara.title: Function &function-lambda-expression;
formalpara.para: The &name-r; of a &foreign-function-t; is a string (the name of the underlying &c-lang; function), not a lisp &funname;.

formalpara.title: Macro &destructuring-bind;
formalpara.para: This macro does not perform full error checking.
These macros are implemented as special operators (as permitted by Section 3.1.2.1.2.2) and, as such, are rather efficient.

section.title: Macro &defconstant;
section.para: The initial value is &not-e; evaluated at compile time, just like with &defvar; and &defparameter;. Use &eval-when; if you need the value at compile time.
It is an error if a &defconstant; variable is bound at the moment the &defconstant; is executed, but &defconstant; does not check this.
&constant;s may not be bound dynamically or lexically.

section.title: Macro EXT:FCASE
section.para:
This macro allows specifying the test for &case;, e.g.,
(fcase string= (subseq foo 0 (position #\Space foo)) ("first" 1) (("second" "two") 2) (("true" "yes") t) (otherwise nil))
is the same as
(let ((var (subseq foo 0 (position #\Space foo)))) (cond ((string= var "first") 1) ((or (string= var "second") (string= var "two")) 2) ((or (string= var "true") (string= var "yes")) t) (t nil)))
If you use a built-in &hash-table-t; test (see ) as the test (e.g., &equal; instead of &string-eq; above, but not a test defined using &defhash;), the compiler will be able to optimize the EXT:FCASE form better than the corresponding &cond; form.

section.title: Function EXT:XOR
Function &eq;
section.para: &eq; compares &character-t;s and &fixnum-t;s as &eql; does. No unnecessary copies are made of &character-t;s and &number-t;s. Nevertheless, one should use &eql; as it is more portable across &cl; implementations.
(&let; ((x y)) (&eq; x x)) always returns &t;, regardless of &y-r;.

warning.para: (&eq; x x) might not be &t; for a &foreign-variable-t; &x-r;.

section.title: Function &symbol-function;
section.para: (&setf; (&symbol-function; &symbol-r;) &object-r;) requires &object-r; to be either a function, a &symbol-function; return value, or a &lambda-expr;. The &lambda-expr; is thereby immediately converted to a &function-t;.

section.title: Macro &setf;
section.para: &key-amp; markers in &defsetf; &lalist;s are supported, but the corresponding keywords must appear literally in the program text.

(&get-setf-expansion; &form-r; &optional-amp; &env-r;), (EXT:GET-SETF-METHOD &form-r; &optional-amp; &env-r;), and (EXT:GET-SETF-METHOD-MULTIPLE-VALUE &form-r; &optional-amp; &env-r;) receive as optional argument &env-r; the environment necessary for macro expansions. In &define-setf-expander; and EXT:DEFINE-SETF-METHOD &lalist;s, one can specify &environment-amp; and a variable, which will be bound to the environment. This environment should be passed to all calls of &get-setf-expansion;, EXT:GET-SETF-METHOD and EXT:GET-SETF-METHOD-MULTIPLE-VALUE. If this is done, even local macros will be interpreted as places correctly.

Attempts to modify read-only data will &signal; an &error-t;. Program text and quoted constants loaded from files are considered read-only data. This check is only performed for strings, not for conses, other kinds of arrays, and user-defined data types.
See also .

section.title: Special Operator &function;
section.para: (&function; &symbol-r;) returns the local function definition established by &flet; or &labels;, if it exists, otherwise the global function definition.

section.title: Macro &define-symbol-macro;
section.para: The macro &define-symbol-macro; establishes &symbol-macro;s with global scope (as opposed to &symbol-macro;s defined with &symbol-macrolet;, which have local scope): (&define-symbol-macro; &symbol-r; expansion).
Calling &boundp; on a symbol defined as a &symbol-macro; returns &t;.
Calling &makunbound; on a symbol defined as a &symbol-macro; removes the &symbol-macro; definition.

section.title: Macros &defun; & &defmacro;
section.para: &defun; and &defmacro; are allowed in non-toplevel positions. As an example, consider the old (&cltl1;) definition of &gensym;:
section.programlisting: (let ((gensym-prefix "G") (gensym-count 1)) (defun gensym (&optional (x nil s)) (when s (cond ((stringp x) (setq gensym-prefix x)) ((integerp x) (if (minusp x) (error "~S: index ~S is negative" 'gensym x) (setq gensym-count x))) (t (error "~S: argument ~S of wrong type" 'gensym x)))) (prog1 (make-symbol (concatenate 'string gensym-prefix (write-to-string gensym-count :base 10 :radix nil))) (incf gensym-count))))

formalpara.title: Variable &suppress-check-redef;
formalpara.para: When &suppress-check-redef; is &nil;, &clisp; issues a &warning-t; when a function (macro, variable, class, etc) is redefined in a different file than its original definition. It is &not-e; a good idea to set this variable to &t;.

formalpara.title: Variable &defun-accept-spelalist;
formalpara.para: When &defun-accept-spelalist; is non-&nil;, &defun; accepts &spelalist;s, converting type-parameter associations to type declarations: (defun f ((x list) (y integer)) ...) is equivalent to (defun f (x y) (declare (type list x) (type integer y)) ...) This extension is disabled by &ansi-opt; and by setting &ansi; to &t;, but can be re-enabled by setting &defun-accept-spelalist; explicitly.

section.title: Iteration variables in the loop epilogue
section.para: The standard is unambiguous in that the iteration variables do still exist in the &finally; clause, but &not-e; as to what values these variables might have. Therefore the code which relies on the values of such variables, e.g., (loop for x on y finally (return x)) is inherently non-portable across &cl; implementations, and should be avoided.

section.title: Backward Compatibility
section.para:
There have been some tightening in the &loop; syntax between &cltl2; and &ansi-cl;, e.g., the following form is legal in the former but not the latter: (loop initially for i from 1 to 5 do (print i) finally return i)
When &loop-ansi; is &nil;, such forms are still accepted in &clisp; but elicit a warning at macro-expansion time. When &loop-ansi; is non-&nil;, an &err-sig;.

section.title: Standard Method Combination [CLHS-7.6.6.2]
section.para:
Generic function &no-prim; NO-PRIMARY-METHOD
(similar to &no-applicable-method;) is called when there is an applicable method but no applicable primary method.

chapter.title: Structures [CLHS-8]
chapter.para: The &print-function-k; option should contain a &lambda-expr; (&lambda-m; (object stream depth) (declare (ignore depth)) ...) This &lambda-expr; names a &function-t; whose task is to output the external representation of the &structure-object-t; &object-r; onto the &stream-t; &stream-r;. This may be done by outputting text onto the stream using &write-char;, &write-string;, &write;, &prin1;, &princ;, &print;, &pprint;, &format; and the like. The following rules must be obeyed:

listitem.simpara: The value of &print-escape-var; must be respected.
The treatment of &print-pretty-var; is up to you.

The value of &print-circle-var; need not be respected. This is managed by the system. (But the print-circle mechanism handles only those objects that are direct or indirect components of the structure.)

The value of &print-level-var; is respected by &write;, &prin1;, &princ;, &print;, &pprint;, &format; instructions &format-a;, &format-s;, &format-w;, and &format; instructions &format-r;, &format-d;, &format-b;, &format-o;, &format-x;, &format-f;, &format-e;, &format-g;, &format-dollar; with not-numerical arguments. Therefore the print-level mechanism works automatically if only these functions are used for outputting objects and if they are not called on objects with nesting level > 1. (The print-level mechanism does not recognize how many parentheses you have output. It only counts how many times it was called recursively.)
The value of &print-length-var; must be respected, especially if you are outputting an arbitrary number of components.

The value of &print-readably-var; must be respected. Remember that the values of &print-escape-var;, &print-level-var;, &print-length-var; are ignored if &print-readably-var; is true. The value of &print-readably-var; is respected by &print-unreadable-object;, &write;, &prin1;, &princ;, &print;, &pprint;, &format; instructions &format-a;, &format-s;, &format-w;, and &format; instructions &format-r;, &format-d;, &format-b;, &format-o;, &format-x;, &format-f;, &format-e;, &format-g;, &format-dollar; with not-numerical arguments. Therefore &print-readably-var; will be respected automatically if only these functions are used for printing objects.
You need not worry about the values of &print-base-var;, &print-radix-var;, &print-case-var;, &print-gensym-var;, &print-array-var;, &pr-closure;, &pr-rpars;, &pr-indent;.

formalpara.title: Option &inherit-k;
formalpara.para: The &inherit-k; option is exactly like &include-k; except that it does not create new accessors for the inherited slots (this is a &clisp; extension).

chapter.title: Conditions [CLHS-9]
chapter.para: When an error occurred, you are in a break loop. You can evaluate forms as usual. The help command (or help key if there is one) lists the available debugging commands.

formalpara.title: Macro &muffle-cerrors;
Macro &appease-cerrors;
formalpara.para: The macro (&appease-cerrors; {&form-r;}*) executes the &form-r;s; when a &cont-err; occurs whose &continue; &restart-t; can be invoked non-interactively (this includes all &cont-err;s &signal;ed by the function &cerror;), it is reported as a &warning-t;, and the &continue; &restart-t; is invoked.

formalpara.title: Macro &abort-on-error;
formalpara.para: The macro (&abort-on-error; {&form-r;}*) executes the &form-r;s; when an &error-t; occurs, or when a &ctrl;C interrupt occurs, the error message is printed and the &abort-s; restart is invoked.

formalpara.title: Macro &exit-on-error;
formalpara.para: The macro (&exit-on-error; {&form-r;}*) executes the &form-r;s; when an &error-t; occurs, or when a &ctrl;C interrupt occurs, the error message is printed and &clisp; terminates with an error status.

formalpara.title: Variable &err-pr-bt;
formalpara.para: When this variable is non-&nil; the error message printed by &abort-on-error; and &exit-on-error; includes the backtrace (stack).

formalpara.title: Function &set-global-handler;
formalpara.para: The function (&set-global-handler; &cond-r; handler) establishes a global handler for the &cond-r;. The handler should be &funcall;able (a &symbol-t; or a &function-t;). If it returns, the next applicable handler is invoked, so if you do not want to land in the debugger, it should &not-e; return. E.g., the option &opt-on-error; abort and the macro &abort-on-error; are implemented by installing the following handler: (defun sys::abortonerror (condition) (sys::report-error condition) (invoke-restart (find-restart 'abort condition))) When handler is &nil;, the handler for &cond-r; is removed and returned. When &cond-r; is also &nil;, all global handlers are removed and returned as a &list-t;, which can then be passed to &set-global-handler; as the first argument and the handlers re-established.

formalpara.title: Macro &without-global-handlers;
Macro &with-restarts;
formalpara.para: The macro &with-restarts; is like &restart-case;, except that the forms are specified after the restart clauses instead of before them, and the restarts created are not implicitly associated with any &condition-t;. (&with-restarts; ({&restart-clause-r;}*) {&form-r;}*) is therefore equivalent to (&restart-case; (&progn; {&form-r;}*) {&restart-clause-r;}*).

section.title: Embedded Newlines in Condition Reports [CLHS-9.1.3.1.3]
section.para: The error message prefix for the first line is *** - . All subsequent lines are indented by 6 characters. Long lines are broken on &whitespace; (see ).

formalpara.title: Macro &restart-case;
formalpara.para: In (&restart-case; &form-r; {&restart-clause-r;}*), the argument list can also be specified after the keyword/value pairs instead of before them, i.e., each &restart-clause-r; can be either (restart-name &args; {keyword-value-pair}* {&form-r;}*) or (restart-name {keyword-value-pair}* &args; {&form-r;}*).

formalpara.title: Function &compute-restarts;
formalpara.para: &compute-restarts; and &find-restart; behave as specified in &ansi-cl;: If the optional &cond-r; argument is non-&nil;, only restarts associated with that condition and restarts associated with no condition at all are considered. Therefore the effect of associating a restart to a condition is not to activate it, but to hide it from other conditions. This makes the syntax-dependent implicit association performed by &restart-case; nearly obsolete.

section.title: Constraints on the &cl-pac; Package for Conforming Programs - package locking [CLHS-11.1.2.1.2]

formalpara.title: Function &package-lock;
formalpara.para:
PACKAGE-LOCK
Packages can be locked. When a package is locked, attempts to change its symbol table or redefine functions which its symbols name result in a &cont-err; (continuing overrides locking for this operation). When &suppress-check-redef; is &t; (&not-e; a good idea!), the &error-t; is not &signal;ed for redefine operations. Function (&package-lock; &pack-r;) returns the generalized boolean indicating whether the &pack-r; is locked. A package (or a list thereof) can be locked using (&setf; (&package-lock; package-or-list) &t;). &clisp; locks its system packages (specified in the variable &sys-pack-list;).

formalpara.title: Macro &without-package-lock;
formalpara.para:
If you want to evaluate some forms with certain packages unlocked, you can use &without-package-lock;
WITHOUT-PACKAGE-LOCK :
(&without-package-lock; (&cl-pac; &ext-pac; &clos-pac;) (defun restart () ...))
or
(&without-package-lock; (&cl-pac;) (trace read-line))
(&without-package-lock; () ...) temporarily unlocks all packages in &sys-pack-list;.

formalpara.title: Variable &sys-pack-list;
formalpara.para: This variable specifies the default packages to be locked by &savemem; and unlocked by &without-package-lock; as a list of package names. You may add names to this list, e.g., a module will add its package, but you should &not-e; remove &clisp; internal packages from this list.

formalpara.title: Discussion - see also the USENET posting by Steven M. Haflich haflich@pacbell.net
formalpara.para:
This should prevent you from accidentally hosing yourself with
(&defstruct; instance ...)
and allow enforcing modularity. Note that you will also get the &cont-err; when you try to assign (with &setq;, &psetq;, etc.) a value to an internal special variable living in a locked package and not accessible in your current &package-var;, but only in the interpreted code and during compilation. There is no check for package locks in compiled code because of the performance considerations.

section.title: The COMMON-LISP-USER Package [CLHS-11.1.2.2]
section.para: The &clu-pac; package uses the &cl-pac; and &ext-pac; packages.

section.title: Implementation-Defined Packages [CLHS-11.1.2.4]
section.para: The following additional packages exist:

listitem.simpara: &export;s all &clos;-specific symbols, including some additional symbols.
has the nicknames SYS and COMPILER, and has no &export;ed symbols. It defines many system internals.

is the umbrella package for all extensions: it imports and &re-export;s all the external symbols in all &clisp; extensions, so a simple (&use-package; "EXT") is enough to make all the extensions available in the current package. This package uses packages (in addition to &cl-pac;): &ldap-pac;, &posix-pac;, &socket-pac;, &gstream-pac;, &gray-pac;, &i18n-pac;, &custom-pac;.
defines and &export;s some character sets, for use with &make-encoding; and as &extfmt; argument.
implements the foreign function interface. Some platforms only.
defines an API for random screen access. Some platforms only.
case-sensitive versions of &cl-pac; and &clu-pac;. See .

section.para: All pre-existing packages except &clu-pac; belong to the implementation, in the sense that the programs that do not follow Section 11.1.2.1.2 ("Constraints on the &cl-pac; Package for Conforming Programs") cause undefined behavior.

section.title: Package Case-Sensitivity
section.para: &clisp; supports programs written with case sensitive symbols. For example, with case sensitive symbols, the symbols cdr (the function equivalent to &rest;) and the symbol CDR (a user-defined type denoting a Call Data Record) are different and unrelated.

There are some incompatibilities between programs assuming case sensitive symbols and programs assuming the &ansi-cl; case insensitive symbols. For example, (eq 'KB 'Kb) evaluates to false in a case sensitive world and to true in a case insensitive world. However, unlike some commercial &cl; implementations, &clisp; allows both kinds of programs to coexist in the same process and interoperate with each other. Example:
OLD.lisp
(&in-package; "OLD") (&defun; FOO () ...)
modern.lisp
(in-package "NEW") (defun bar () (old:foo)) (symbol-name 'bar) ; "bar"

This is achieved through specification of the symbol case policy at the package level. A modern package
&package-t; modern is one that is declared to be both case-sensitive and case-inverted and which use the symbols from the &cs-cl; package.

A case-sensitive package
&package-t; case-sensitive is one whose &defpackage; declaration (or &make-package; creation form) has the option (&case-sensitive-k; &t;). In a case-sensitive package, the reader does &not-e; uppercase the symbol name before calling &intern;. Similarly, the printer, when printing the &symbol-name; part of a &symbol-t; (i.e. the part after the package markers), behaves as if the readtable's case were set to :PRESERVE. See also .

A case-inverted package
&package-t; case-inverted is one whose &defpackage; declaration (or &make-package; creation form) has the option (&case-inverted-k; &t;). In the context of a case-inverted package, symbol names are case-inverted: upper case characters are mapped to lower case, lower case characters are mapped to upper case, and other characters are left untouched. Every symbol thus conceptually has two symbol names: an old-world symbol name and a modern-world symbol name, which is the case-inverted old-world name. The first symbol name is returned by the function &symbol-name;, the modern one by the function cs-cl:symbol-name. The internal functions for creating or looking up symbols in a package, which traditionally took a string argument, now conceptually take two string arguments: old-style-string and inverted-string. Actually, a function like &intern; takes the old-style-string as argument and computes the inverted-string from it; whereas the function cs-cl:intern takes the inverted-string as argument and computes the old-style-string from it. See also .

For a few built-in functions, a variant for the case-inverted world is defined in the &cs-cl; package, which has the nickname CS-CL: cs-cl:symbol-name returns the case-inverted symbol name.
cs-cl:intern cs-cl:find-symbol work consistently with cs-cl:symbol-name. cs-cl:shadow cs-cl:find-all-symbols cs-cl:string= cs-cl:string/= cs-cl:string< cs-cl:string> cs-cl:string<= cs-cl:string>= cs-cl:string-trim cs-cl:string-left-trim cs-cl:string-right-trim convert a &symbol-t; to a &string-t; and therefore exist in a variant that uses cs-cl:symbol-name instead of &symbol-name;. cs-cl:make-package creates a case-inverted &package-t;.

section.title: User Package for the Case-sensitive World
section.para: A package &cs-clu; is provided for the user to modify and work in. It plays the same role as &clu-pac;, but for the case-sensitive world.

section.title: Package Names
section.para: The handling of package names is unchanged. Package names are still usually uppercase. The package names are also subject to (&readtable-case; &readtable-var;).

section.title: Gensyms and Keywords
section.para: Note that gensyms and keywords are still treated traditionally: even in a case-sensitive package, (&eq; #:FooBar #:foobar) and (&eq; ':KeyWord ':keyword) evaluate to true. We believe this has limited negative impact for the moment, but can be changed a few years from now.

section.title: Migration Tips
section.para:
The following practices will pose no problems when migrating to a modern case-sensitive world:
Using &ansi-cl; symbols in lowercase. Macros that create symbols by suffixing or prefixing given symbols. Comparing symbol names as in (string= (symbol-name x) (symbol-name y)).

The following practices will not work in a case-sensitive world or can give problems:
Accessing the same symbol in both upper- and lowercase from the same source file. Macros that create symbols in other packages than the original symbols. Comparing symbol-name return values with &eq;.
Comparing (&symbol-name; x) with (cs-cl:symbol-name y).

section.title: Using case-sensitive packages by default
section.para: &clisp; supports a command-line option &opt-modern; that sets the &package-var; initially to the &cs-clu; package, and &print-base-var; to :DOWNCASE.

section.title: Function &make-package;
section.para: The default value of the &use-k; argument is (&cl-pac;).
&make-package; accepts additional keyword arguments &case-sensitive-k; and &case-inverted-k; (but &not-e; &modern-k;!)

section.title: Macro &defpackage;
section.para: &defpackage; accepts additional options &case-sensitive-k;, &case-inverted-k;, and &modern-k;.

section.title: Function &re-export;
section.para: The function (&re-export; FROM-PACK TO-PACK) re-&export;s all external &symbol-t;s from FROM-PACK also from TO-PACK, provided it already uses FROM-PACK; and &signal;s an &error-t; otherwise.

section.title: Function &pack-inverted;
section.para: Returns &t; if the argument is a case-inverted package. This function is &setf;able, although it is probably not a good idea to change the case-inverted status of an existing package.

section.title: Function &pack-sensitive;
section.para: Returns &t; if the argument is a case-sensitive package. This function is &setf;able, although it is probably not a good idea to change the case-sensitive status of an existing package.

section.title: Numeric Types
section.para: The type &number-t; is the disjoint union of the types &real-t; and &complex-t; (exhaustive partition)
The type &real-t; is the disjoint union of the types &rational-t; and &float-t;.
The type &rational-t; is the disjoint union of the types &integer-t; and &ratio-t;.
The type &integer-t; is the disjoint union of the types &fixnum-t; and &bignum-t;.
The type &float-t; is the disjoint union of the types &short-float-t;, &single-float-t;, &double-float-t; and &long-float-t;.

section.title: Byte Operations on Integers [CLHS-12.1.1.3.2]
section.para: Byte specifiers are objects of built-in type &byte-t;, not &integer-t;s.

section.title: Rule of Float Substitutability [CLHS-12.1.3.3]
section.para: When a mathematical function may return an exact (&rational-t;) or inexact (&float-t;) result, it always returns the exact result.

section.title: Floating-point Computations [CLHS-12.1.4]
section.para: The single and double float formats are those of the &ieee-bfp; Standard for Binary Floating-Point Arithmetic, except that &clisp; does not support features like ±0, ±inf, NaN, gradual underflow, etc. &cl; does not make use of these features, so, to reduce portability problems, &clisp; by design returns the same floating point results on all platforms (&clisp; has a floating-point emulation built in for platforms that do not support &ieee-bfp;). Note that When you got a NaN in your program, your program is broken, so you will spend time determining where the NaN came from. It is better to &signal; an &error-t; in this case. When you got unnormalized floats in your program, your results will have a greatly reduced accuracy anyway. Since &clisp; has the means to cope with this - &long-float-t;s of variable precision - it does not need unnormalized floats. This is why &features-my; does not contain the :IEEE-FLOATING-POINT keyword.

formalpara.title: Arbitrary Precision Floats
formalpara.para: &long-float-t;s have variable mantissa length, which is a multiple of 16 (or 32, depending on the word size of the processor). The default length used when &long-float-t;s are &read; is given by the &place; &lfd-l;. It can be set by (&setf; (&lfd;) &n-r;), where &n-r; is a positive &integer-t;. E.g., (&setf; (&lfd;) 3322) sets the default precision of &long-float-t;s to about 1000 decimal digits.

section.title: Rule of Float Precision Contagion [CLHS-12.1.4.4]
section.para: The floating point contagion is controlled by the variable &flocont;. When it is non-&nil;, contagion is done as per the &ansi-cl;: &short-float-t; → &single-float-t; → &double-float-t; → &long-float-t;.

listitem.simpara: See it pragmatically: save what you can and let others worry about the rest.

&cl; knows the number's precision, not accuracy, so preserving the precision can be accomplished reliably, while anything relating to the accuracy is just a speculation - only the user (programmer) knows what it is in each case.

A computer float is an approximation of a real number. One can think of it as a random variable with the mean equal to itself and standard deviation equal to half the last significant digit. E.g., 1.5 is actually 1.5±0.05. Consider adding 1.5 and 1.75. &ansi-cl; requires that (+ 1.5 1.75) return 3.25, while traditional &clisp; would return 3.3. The implied random variables are: 3.25±0.005 and 3.3±0.05. Note that the traditional &clisp; way does lie about the mean: the mean &is-e; 3.25 and nothing else, while the standard way could be lying about the deviation (accuracy): if the implied accuracy of 1.5 (0.05) is its actual accuracy, then the accuracy of the result cannot be smaller that that. Therefore, since &cl; has no way of knowing the actual accuracy, &ansi-cl; (and all the other standard engineering programming languages, like &c-lang;, FORTRAN etc) decides that keeping the accuracy correct is the business of the programmer, while the language should preserve what it can - the precision.

Rounding errors accumulate, and if a computation is conducted with insufficient precision, an outright incorrect result can be returned. (E.g., E(x2) - E(x)2 can be negative!) The user should not mix floats of different precision (that's what &warn-fpc; is for), but one should not be penalized for this too harshly.

section.para: When &flocont; is &nil;, the traditional &clisp; method is used, namely the result of an arithmetic operation whose arguments are of different float types is rounded to the float format of the shortest (least precise) of the arguments: &rational-t; → &long-float-t; → &double-float-t; → &single-float-t; → &short-float-t; (in contrast to 12.1.4.4 Rule of Float Precision Contagion!)

listitem.simpara: See it mathematically. Add intervals: {1.0 ± 1e-8} + {1.0 ± 1e-16} = {2.0 ± 1e-8}. So, if we add 1.0s0 and 1.0d0, we should get 2.0s0.
Do not suggest accuracy of a result by giving it a precision that is greater than its accuracy.
(&subt; (+ 1.7 &pi-v;) &pi-v;) should not return 1.700000726342836417234L0, it should return 1.7f0 (or 1.700001f0 if there were rounding errors).

If in a computation using thousands of &short-float-t;s, a &long-float-t; (like &pi-v;) happens to be used, the long precision should not propagate throughout all the intermediate values. Otherwise, the long result would look precise, but its accuracy is only that of a &short-float-t;; furthermore much computation time would be lost by calculating with &long-float-t;s when only &short-float-t;s would be needed.

simplesect.title: Variable &warn-fpc;
simplesect.para: If the variable &warn-fpc; is non-&nil;, a &warning-t; is emitted for every coercion involving different floating-point types. As explained above, float precision contagion is not a good idea. You can avoid the contagion by doing all your computations with the same floating-point type (and using &float; to convert all constants, e.g., &pi-v;, to your preferred type).

This variable helps you eliminate all occurrences of float precision contagion: set it to &t; to have &clisp; &signal; a &warning-t; on float precision contagion; set it to &error; to have &clisp; &signal; an &error-t; on float precision contagion, so that you can look at the stack backtrace.

section.title: Rule of Float and Rational Contagion [CLHS-12.1.4.1]
section.para: The contagion between floating point and rational numbers is controlled by the variable &floratcont;. When it is non-&nil;, contagion is done as per the &ansi-cl;: &rational-t; → &float-t;.

When &floratcont; is &nil;, the traditional &clisp; method is used, namely if the result is mathematically an exact rational number, this rational number is returned (in contrast to 12.1.4.1 Rule of Float and Rational Contagion!)

&floratcont; has an effect only in those few cases when the mathematical result is exact although one of the arguments is a floating-point number, such as (☆ 0 1.618), (&slash; 0 1.618), (&atan; 0 1.0), (&expt; 2.0 0), (&phase; 2.718).

simplesect.title: Variable &warn-fprc;
simplesect.para: If the variable &warn-fprc; is non-&nil;, a &warning-t; is emitted for every avoidable coercion from a rational number to a floating-point number. You can avoid such coercions by calling &float; to convert the particular rational numbers to your preferred floating-point type.

This variable helps you eliminate all occurrences of avoidable coercions to a floating-point number when a rational number result would be possible: set it to &t; to have &clisp; &signal; a &warning-t; in such situations; set it to &error; to have &clisp; &signal; an &error-t; in such situations, so that you can look at the stack backtrace.

simplesect.title: Variable &phasecont;

section.title: Complex Computations [CLHS-12.1.5]
section.para: Complex numbers can have a real part and an imaginary part of different types. For example, (&sqrt; -9.0) evaluates to the number #C(0 3.0), which has a real part of exactly &zero;, not only 0.0 (which would mean approximately 0).
The type specifier (&complex-t; &type-r;) is equivalent to (&complex-t; &type-r; &type-r;).

section.title: Rule of Canonical Representation for Complex Rationals [CLHS-12.1.5.3]
section.para: Complex numbers can have a real part and an imaginary part of different types. If the imaginary part is &eql; to &zero;, the number is automatically converted to a real number.
This has the advantage that (&let; ((x (&sqrt; -9.0))) (* x x)) - instead of evaluating to #C(-9.0 0.0), with &x-r; = #C(0.0 3.0) - evaluates to #C(-9.0 0) = -9.0, with &x-r; = #C(0 3.0).

section.title: Random Numbers
section.para: To ease reproducibility, the variable &random-state-var; is initialized to the same value on each invocation, so that &sh-prompt; clisp -norc &opt-x; '(&random; 1s0)' will always print the same number.

formalpara.title: Function EXT:!
formalpara.para: (EXT:! &n-r;) returns the factorial of &n-r;, &n-r; being a nonnegative &integer-t;.

formalpara.title: Function EXT:EXQUO
formalpara.para: (EXT:EXQUO &x-r; &y-r;) returns the integer quotient x/y of two integers &x-r;,&y-r;, and &signal;s an &error-t; when the quotient is not integer. (This is more efficient than &slash;.)

formalpara.title: Function EXT:XGCD
formalpara.para:
(EXT:XGCD &x1-r; ... &xn-r;) returns the values &l-r;, &k1-r;, ..., &kn-r;, where &l-r; is the greatest common divisor of the integers &x1-r;, ..., &xn-r;, and &k1-r;, ..., &kn-r; are the integer coefficients such that
&l-r; = (&gcd; &x1-r; ... &xn-r;) = (+ (* &k1-r; &x1-r;) ... (* &kn-r; &xn-r;))

formalpara.title: Function EXT:MOD-EXPT
formalpara.para: (EXT:MOD-EXPT &k-r; &l-r; &m-r;) is equivalent to (&mod; (&expt; &k-r; &l-r;) &m-r;) except it is more efficient for very large arguments.

formalpara.title: Function &expt;
formalpara.para: (&expt; &base-r; exponent) is not very precise if exponent has a large absolute value.

formalpara.title: Function &log;
formalpara.para: (&log; &number-r; &base-r;) &sig-err; if &base-r; = 1.

formalpara.title: Constant &pi-v;
formalpara.para: The value of &pi-v; is a &long-float-t; with the precision given by &lfd-l;. When this precision is changed, the value of &pi-v; is automatically recomputed. Therefore &pi-v; is &not-e; a &constant;.

formalpara.title: Function &upgraded-complex-part-type;
formalpara.para: When the argument is not a &recog-subt; or &real-t;, &upgraded-complex-part-type; &signal;s an &error-t;, otherwise it returns its argument (even though a &complex-t; number in &clisp; can always have ℜ and ℑ of any type) because it allows the most precise type inference.

formalpara.title: Variable &default-float-format;
formalpara.para: When rational numbers are to be converted to floats (due to &float;, &coerce;, &sqrt; or a transcendental function), the result type is given by the variable &default-float-format;.

formalpara.title: Macro &no-underflow;
formalpara.para: The macro (&no-underflow; {&form-r;}*) executes the &form-r;s, with errors of type &floating-point-underflow-t; inhibited. Floating point operations will silently return zero instead of &signal;ing an &error-t; of type &floating-point-underflow-t;.

formalpara.title: Condition &floating-point-invalid-operation-t;
formalpara.para: This &condition-t; is never &signal;ed by &clisp;.

formalpara.title: Condition &floating-point-inexact-t;
formalpara.para: This &condition-t; is never &signal;ed by &clisp;.

section.title: Float Decoding [CLHS]
section.para: &float-radix; always returns 2.

(&float-digits; &number-r; &digits-r;) coerces &number-r; (a &real-t;) to a floating point number with at least &digits-r; mantissa digits. The following always evaluates to &t;:
(≥ (&float-digits; (&float-digits; &number-r; &digits-r;)) &digits-r;)

section.title: Bignum Limits [CLHS]
section.para: &bignum-t;s are limited in size. Their maximum size is 32*(216-2)=2097088 bits. The largest representable &bignum-t; is therefore 22097088-1.

chapter.title: Characters [CLHS-13]
chapter.para: The characters are ordered according to a superset of the &charset-ascii;.

listitem.simpara: More precisely, &clisp; uses the 21-bit &unicode; 3.2 character set (ISO 10646, also known as UCS-4).

term.emphasis: &unix; (except &nextstep;), &win32; platforms only, and only in &clisp; built &without; compile-time flag &unicode;.
&nextstep; platforms only, and only in &clisp; built &without; compile-time flag &unicode;.

section.title: Character Scripts [CLHS-13.1.2.1]
section.para: The only defined character script is the type &character-t; itself.

section.title: Character Attributes [CLHS-13.1.3]
section.para: Characters have no implementation-defined or &cltl1; font and bit attributes. All characters are simple characters.

section.title: Input Characters

listitem.simpara: The system uses only font 0.

returns a new &input-char;, or &nil; if such a character cannot be created.

The system itself uses this &input-char; type only to mention special keys and &ctrl;/&alt;/&shift; key status on return from (&read-char; &kbd-in;).

section.title: Graphic Characters [CLHS-13.1.4.1]
section.para: The &graphic; characters are those &unicode; characters which are defined by the &unicode; standard, excluding the ranges U0000 … U001F and U007F … U009F.

section.title: Alphabetic Characters [CLHS-13.1.4.2]
section.para:
The alphabetic characters are those &unicode; characters which are defined as letters by the &unicode; standard, e.g., the &ascii; characters ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz
and the international alphabetic characters from the character set: ÇüéâäàåçêëèïîìÄÅÉæÆôöòûùÿÖÜßáíóúñÑªºãõØøÀÃÕ etc.

section.title: Function &char-invertcase;
section.para: (&char-invertcase; &ch-r;) returns the corresponding character in the other case for &char;, i.e., &char-upcase; for a lowercase character and &char-downcase; for an uppercase character; for a character that does not have a case attribute, the argument is returned. See also &string-invertcase; and &nstring-invertcase;.

section.title: Case of Implementation-Defined Characters [CLHS-13.1.4.3.4]
section.para: The titlecase property of &unicode; characters has no equivalent in &cl;.

section.title: Numeric Characters [CLHS-13.1.4.4]
section.para: The numeric characters are those &unicode; characters which are defined as digits by the &unicode; standard.

section.title: Ordering of Characters [CLHS-13.1.6]
section.para: The characters are ordered according to their &unicode; code.
The functions &char-equal; &char-not-equal;, &char-lessp;, &char-greaterp;, &char-not-greaterp;, &char-not-lessp; ignore bits and font attributes of their arguments.

section.title: Treatment of Newline during Input and Output [CLHS-13.1.8]
section.para: Newlines are written according to the stream's &encoding;, see the function &stream-external-format; and the description of &encoding;s, in particular, &line-term;s. The default behavior is as follows:

listitem.simpara: When writing to a file, &nl-s; is converted to &cr-c;/&lf-c;. (This is the usual convention on &dos;.) For example, &cr-s;+&nl-s; is written as &cr-c;/&cr-c;/&lf-c;.

section.para: When reading from a file, &cr-c;/&lf-c; is converted to &nl-s; (the usual convention on &dos;), and &cr-c; not followed by &lf-c; is converted to &nl-s; as well (the usual conversion on MacOS, also used by some programs on &win32;). If you do not want this, i.e., if you really want to distinguish &lf-c;, &cr-c; and &cr-c;/&lf-c;, you have to resort to binary input (function &read-byte;).

formalpara.title: Justification
formalpara.para: Unicode Newline Guidelines say: Even if you know which characters represents NLF on your particular platform, on input and in interpretation, treat CR, LF, CRLF, and NEL the same. Only on output do you need to distinguish between them.

formalpara.title: Rationale
formalpara.para: In &clisp;, &nl-s; is identical to &lf-s; (which is specifically permitted by &ansi-cl; in section 13.1.7 Character Names). Consider a file containing exactly this string: (&concatenate; '&string-any; "foo" (&string; &lf-s;) "bar" (&string; &cr-s;) (&string; &lf-s;)) Suppose we open it with (&open; "foo" &extfmt; &dos-k;). What should &read-line; return? Right now, it returns "foo" (the second &read-line; returns "bar" and reaches &eos;). If our i/o were faithful, &read-line; would have returned the string (&concatenate; '&string-any; "foo" (&string; &lf-s;) "bar"), i.e., a string with an embedded &nl-s; between "foo" and "bar" (because a single &lf-s; is not a &nl-s; in the specified &extfmt;, it will not make &read-line; return, but it &is-e; a &clisp; &nl-s;!) Even though the specification for &read-line; does not explicitly forbids newlines inside the returned string, such behavior would be quite surprising, to say the least. Moreover, this line (with an embedded &nl-s;) would be written as two lines (when writing to a &stream-t; with &extfmt; of &dos-k;), because the embedded &nl-s; would be written as &cr-c;+&lf-c;.

section.title: Character Encodings [CLHS-13.1.9]
section.para: The integer returned by &char-int; is the same as the character's code (&char-code;).

section.title: Documentation of Implementation-Defined Scripts [CLHS-13.1.10]
section.para: See .

section.title: Function &char-code;
section.para: &char-code; takes values from &zero; (inclusive) to &char-code-limit; (exclusive), i.e., the implementation supports exactly &char-code-limit; characters.

section.title: Type &base-char-t;
section.para: The types EXT:STRING-CHAR (removed by &iss026;) and &base-char-t; are equivalent to &character-t;.

section.title: Function &char-width;
section.para: (&char-width; &ch-r;) returns the number of screen columns occupied by &ch-r;. This is 0 for non-spacing characters (such as control characters and many combining characters), 2 for double-width East Asian characters, and 1 for all other characters. See also function &string-width;.

section.title: Platform-Dependent Characters
section.para: The characters that are not &graphic; chars and the space character have names:

formalpara.title: Function &mapcap;
formalpara.para: The function &mapcap; is like &mapcan;, except that it concatenates the resulting lists with &append; instead of &nconc;: (&mapcap; &func-r; &x1-r; ... &xn-r;) ≡ (&apply; #'&append; (&mapcar; &func-r; &x1-r; ... &xn-r;)) (Actually a bit more efficient that this would have been.)

formalpara.title: Function &maplap;
formalpara.para: The function &maplap; is like &mapcon;, except that it concatenates the resulting lists with &append; instead of &nconc;: (&maplap; &func-r; &x1-r; ... &xn-r;) ≡ (&apply; #'&append; (&maplist; &func-r; &x1-r; ... &xn-r;)) (Actually a bit more efficient that this would have been.)

formalpara.title: Function &make-array;
formalpara.para: &make-array; can return specialized arrays for the &array-element-type;s (&unsigned-byte-t; 2), (&unsigned-byte-t; 4), &ubyte-8;, &ubyte-16;, &ubyte-32;, and, of course, the required specializations &nil-t;, &bit-t; and &character-t;.

formalpara.title: Function &adjust-array; for displaced arrays
formalpara.para: An array to which another array is displaced should not be shrunk (using &adjust-array;) in such a way that the other array points into void space. This cannot be checked at the time &adjust-array; is called!

section.title: String Comparison
section.para: String comparison (&string-lst; and friends) is based on the function &char-leq; (see ). Therefore diphthongs do not obey the usual national rules. Example: o < oe < z < ö.

section.title: Function &string-width;
section.para: (&string-width; &string-r; &key-amp; &start-r; &end-r;) returns the number of screen columns occupied by &string-r;. This is computed as the sum of all &char-width;s of all of the &string-r;'s characters: (&reduce; #'+ &string-r; &key-k; #'&char-width;)

section.title: Functions &string-invertcase; and &nstring-invertcase;
section.para: (&string-invertcase; &string-r; &key-amp; &start-r; &end-r;) and (&nstring-invertcase; &string-r; &key-amp; &start-r; &end-r;) are similar to &string-upcase; et al: they use &char-invertcase; to invert the case of each characters in the argument string region.

section.title: Macro &doseq;
section.para: For iteration through a sequence, a macro &doseq;, similar to &dolist;, may be used instead of &map-f;:
&doseq; forms are &iter-form;s.

formalpara.title: Function &nreverse;
formalpara.para: The result of &nreverse; is always &eq; to the argument. &nreverse; on a &vector-t; swaps pairs of elements. &nreverse; on a &list-t; swaps the first and the last element and reverses the list chaining between them.

formalpara.title: Function &nreconc;
formalpara.para: The result of &nreconc; is &eq; to the first argument unless it is &nil;, in which case the result is &eq; to the second argument.

section.title: Functions &remove; & &delete;
section.para: &remove;, &remove-if;, &remove-if-not;, &remove-duplicates; return their argument unchanged, if no element has to be removed.

&delete;, &delete-if;, &delete-if-not;, &delete-duplicates; destructively modify their argument: If the argument is a &list-t;, the &cdr; parts are modified. If the argument is a &vector-t; with fill pointer, the fill pointer is lowered and the remaining elements are compacted below the new fill pointer.

formalpara.title: Variable &count-ansi;
formalpara.para: Contrary to the &ansi-cl; issue &iss283;, negative &count-k; keyword arguments are not allowed unless you set &count-ansi; to a non-&nil; value, in which case using a negative integer value is functionally equivalent to using a value of zero, as per the &ansi-cl; issue.

section.title: Functions &sort; & &stable-sort;
section.para: &sort; and &stable-sort; accept two additional keyword arguments &start-k; and &end-k;:

&sort; and &stable-sort; are identical. They implement the mergesort algorithm. Worst case complexity: O(n*log(n)) comparisons, where &n-r; is the &length; of the subsequence bounded by the &start-k; and &end-k; arguments.

section.title: Function &make-hash-table;
section.para: &make-hash-table; accepts two additional keyword arguments :INITIAL-CONTENTS and :WEAK:

The &test-k; argument can be, other than one of the symbols &eq;, &eql;, &equal;, &equalp;, one of the symbols &fasthash-eq; and &stablehash-eq;. Both of these tests use &eq; as the comparison function; they differ in their performance characteristics.
&fasthash-eq; This uses the fastest possible hash function. Its drawback is that its hash codes become invalid at every &gc;ion (except if all keys are &immediate-o;s), thus requiring a reorganization of the hash table at the first access after each &gc;ion. Especially when generational &gc;ion is used, which leads to frequent small &gc;ions, large hash table with this test can lead to scalability problems. &stablehash-eq; This uses a slower hash function that has the property that its hash codes for instances of the classes &symbol-t;, &standard-stablehash; (subclass of &standard-object-t;) and &structure-stablehash; (subclass of &structure-object-t;) are stable across GCs. This test can thus avoid the scalability problems if all keys, other than &immediate-o;s, are &symbol-t;, &standard-stablehash; or &structure-stablehash; instances.
One can recommend to use &fasthash-eq; for short-lived hash tables. For tables with a longer lifespan which can be big or accessed frequently, it is recommended to use &stablehash-eq;, and to modify the objects that are used as its keys to become instances of &standard-stablehash; or &structure-stablehash;.
When the symbol &eq; or the function #'eq is used as a &test-k; argument, the value of the variable CUSTOM:*EQ-HASHFUNCTION* is used instead. This value must be one of &fasthash-eq;, &stablehash-eq;.

Similarly, the &test-k; argument can also be one of the symbols EXT:FASTHASH-EQL, EXT:STABLEHASH-EQL, EXT:FASTHASH-EQUAL, EXT:STABLEHASH-EQUAL. The same remarks apply as for &fasthash-eq; and &stablehash-eq;. When the symbol &eql; or the function #'eql is used as a &test-k; argument, the value of the variable CUSTOM:*EQL-HASHFUNCTION* is used instead; this value must be one of EXT:FASTHASH-EQL, EXT:STABLEHASH-EQL. Similarly, when the symbol &equal; or the function #'equal is used as a &test-k; argument, the value of the variable CUSTOM:*EQUAL-HASHFUNCTION* is used instead; this value must be one of EXT:FASTHASH-EQUAL, EXT:STABLEHASH-EQUAL.

The :WARN-IF-NEEDS-REHASH-AFTER-GC argument, if true, causes a &warning-t; to be &signal;ed when an object is stored into the table which will force table reorganizations at the first access of the table after each &gc;ion. This keyword argument can be used to check whether &stablehash-eq; should be preferred over &fasthash-eq; for a particular table. Use HASH-TABLE-WARN-IF-NEEDS-REHASH-AFTER-GC to check and &setf; this parameter after the table has been created.
The :INITIAL-CONTENTS argument is an &alist; that is used to initialize the new hash table.
The :REHASH-THRESHOLD argument is ignored.
The &setf;able predicate EXT:HASH-TABLE-WEAK-P checks whether the &hash-table-t; is weak.
Note that the only test that makes sense for weak hash tables are &eq; and its variants &fasthash-eq; and &stablehash-eq;.
Just like all other weak objects, weak &hash-table-t;s cannot be printed readably.
See also .

section.title: Interaction between &hash-table-t;s and &gc;ion
section.para: What can be done to avoid the inefficiencies detected by these warnings? In many cases you can solve the problem by using the STABLEHASH variant of the hash test. In other cases, namely &standard-object-t; or &structure-object-t; instances, you can solve the problem by making the key object classes inherit from &standard-stablehash; or &structure-stablehash;, respectively. In the remaining cases, you should store a hash key inside the object, of which you can guarantee uniqueness through your application (for example the ID of an object in a database, or the serial number of an object), and use this key as hash key instead of the original object.

section.title: Macro &defhash;
section.para: You can define a new hash table test using the macro &defhash;: (&defhash; test-name &test-f; &hash-f;), after which test-name can be passed as the &test-k; argument to &make-hash-table;. E.g.: (&defhash; string &string-eq; &sxhash;) (&make-hash-table; :test 'string) (which is not too useful because it is equivalent to an &equal; &hash-table-t; but less efficient).

The fundamental requirement is that the &test-f; and &hash-f; are consistent: (&funcall; &test-f; &x-r; &y-r;) ⇒ (&areq; (&funcall; &hash-f; &x-r;) (&funcall; &hash-f; &y-r;))
This means that the following definition: (&defhash; number &areq; &sxhash;) ; broken!
is &not-e; correct because (&areq; 1 1d0) is &t; but (&areq; (&sxhash; 1) (&sxhash; 1d0)) is &nil;. The correct way is, e.g.: (&defhash; number &areq; (&lambda-m; (x) (&sxhash; (&coerce; x '&short-float-t;))))
(note that (&coerce; &x-r; &short-float-t;) does &not-e; cons up &fresh; objects while (&coerce; &x-r; &double-float-t;) does).

section.title: Function &hash-table-test;
section.para: Function &hash-table-test; returns either one of &fasthash-eq;, &stablehash-eq;, EXT:FASTHASH-EQL, EXT:STABLEHASH-EQL, EXT:FASTHASH-EQUAL, EXT:STABLEHASH-EQUAL, &equalp; (but not &eq;, &eql; nor &equal; anymore), or, for &hash-table-t;s created with a user-defined &hash-table-test; (see macro &defhash;), a &cons-t; cell (&test-f; . &hash-f;).

section.title: Macro &dohash;
section.para: For iteration through a &hash-table-t;, a macro &dohash;, similar to &dolist;, can be used instead of &maphash;:
&dohash; forms are &iter-form;s.

chapter.title: Filenames [CLHS-19]
chapter.para: For most operations, pathnames denoting files and pathnames denoting directories cannot be used interchangeably.

listitem.simpara: For example, #P"foo/bar" denotes the file &bar-f; in the directory &foo-f;, while #P"foo/bar/" denotes the subdirectory &bar-f; of the directory &foo-f;.
For example, #P"foo\\bar" denotes the file &bar-f; in the directory &foo-f;, while #P"foo\\bar\\" denotes the subdirectory &bar-f; of the directory &foo-f;.

User variable &dev-prefix; controls translation between &cygwin; pathnames (e.g., #P"/cygdrive/c/gnu/clisp/") and native &win32; pathnames (e.g., #P"C:\\gnu\\clisp\\") When it is set to &nil;, no translations occur and the &cygwin; port will not understand the native paths and the native &win32; port will not understand the &cygwin; paths. When its value is a string, it is used by &parse-namestring; to translate into the appropriate platform-specific representation, so that on &cygwin;, (&parse-namestring; "c:/gnu/clisp/") returns #P"/cygdrive/c/gnu/clisp/", while on &win32; (&parse-namestring; "/cygdrive/c/gnu/clisp/") returns #P"C:/gnu/clisp/". The initial value is "cygdrive", you should edit &config-lisp; to change it.

chapter.para: This is especially important for the directory-handling functions.

table.title: The minimum filename syntax that may be used portably

row.entry: for a file with name xxx
for a file with name xxx and type yy
for a pathname with type yy and no name or with name .yy and no type, depending on the value of &parsedot;.

chapter.para: Hereby xxx denotes 1 to 8 characters, and yy denotes 1 to 3 characters, each of which being either an alphanumeric character or the underscore #\_. Other properties of pathname syntax vary between operating systems.

section.title: Pathname Components [CLHS-19.2.1]
section.para: When a pathname is to be fully specified (no wildcards), that means that no &wild-k;, &wild-inferiors-k; is allowed, no wildcard characters are allowed in the strings, and &name-r; &eq; &nil; may not be allowed either.

section.title: Directory canonicalization
section.para:
As permitted by the &make-pathname; specification, the &pathname-t; directory component is canonicalized when the pathname is constructed:
"" and "." are removed "..", "*", and "**" are converted to :UP, &wild-k; and &wild-inferiors-k;, respectively patterns foo/../ are collapsed

listitem.para: Instead of &file-bsla; one may use &file-slash;, as usual for DOS calls.

listitem.simpara: The wildcard characters: &file-star; matches any sequence of characters, &file-ques; matches any one character.

note.simpara: Due to this name/type splitting rule, there are pathnames that cannot result from &parse-namestring;. To get a pathname whose type contains a dot or whose name contains a dot and whose type is &nil;, &make-pathname; must be used. Example: (&make-pathname; &name-k; "foo.bar").

section.title: :UNSPECIFIC as a Component Value [CLHS-19.2.2.2.3]
section.para: The symbol :UNSPECIFIC is not permitted as a pathname component for any slot of any pathname. It is also illegal to pass it as an argument to &make-pathname;, although it &is-e; a legal argument (treated as &nil;) to &user-homedir-pathname;.
The only use for :UNSPECIFIC is that it is returned by &pathname-device; for &logical-pathname-t;s, as required by [CLHS-19.3.2.1] Unspecific Components of a Logical Pathname.

section.title: External notation
section.para: External notation of pathnames (cf. &parse-namestring; and &namestring;), of course without spaces, [,],{,}:

listitem.para: Name and type may be &string-t;s of any &length; (consisting of &printing; &character-t;s, except &file-slash;).

row.entry: each &name-r; is a subdirectory, &file-bsla; may be replaced by &file-slash;

section.title: Logical Pathnames [CLHS-19.3]
section.para: No notes.

formalpara.title: Pathname Designators
formalpara.para: When &parsename; is &nil;, &symbol-t; is also treated as a pathname designator, namely its &symbol-name; is converted to the operating system's preferred pathname case.

formalpara.title: Function &pathname-match-p;
formalpara.para: &pathname-match-p; does not interpret missing components as wild.

section.title: Function &translate-pathname;
section.para: If &all-k; is specified and non-&nil;, a list of all resulting pathnames, corresponding to all matches of (&pathname-match-p; &source-r; from-wildname), is returned.
If &merge-k; is specified and &nil;, unspecified pieces of to-pathname are not replaced by corresponding pieces of &source-r;.

If &absolute-k; is specified and non-&nil;, the returned pathnames are converted to absolute by merging in the current process' directory, therefore rendering pathnames suitable for the OS and external programs. So, to pass a pathname to an external program, you do (&namestring; (&translate-pathname; &path-r; #P"" #P"" &absolute-k; &t;)) or (&namestring; (&absolute-pathname; &path-r;)).

section.title: Function &translate-logical-pathname;
section.para: &translate-logical-pathname; accepts an additional keyword argument &absolute-k;, similar to .

section.title: Function &parse-namestring;
section.para: (&parse-namestring; &string-r; &optional-amp; &host-r; &defaults-r; &key-amp; &start-r; &end-r; junk-allowed) returns a logical pathname only if &host-r; is a logical host or &host-r; is &nil; and &defaults-r; is a &logical-pathname-t;. To construct a logical pathname from a string, the function &logical-pathname; can be used.

The &ansi-cl; behavior of recognizing logical pathnames when the &string-r; begins with some alphanumeric characters followed by a colon (#\:) can be very confusing (cf. "c:/autoexec.bat", "home:.clisprc" and "prep:/pub/gnu") and therefore is disabled by default. To enable the &ansi-cl; behavior, you should set &parsename; to non-&nil;. Note that this also disables treating &symbol-t;s as &path-des;s.

section.title: Function &merge-pathnames;
section.para: (&merge-pathnames; &path-r; [default-pathname]) returns a logical pathname only if default-pathname is a &logical-pathname-t;. To construct a logical pathname from a &string-t;, the function &logical-pathname; can be used.

When both &path-r; and default-pathname are relative pathnames, the behavior depends on &pathmerge;: when it is &nil;, then &clisp; retains its traditional behavior: (&merge-pathnames; #P"x/" #P"y/") evaluates to #P"x/"

formalpara.title: Rationale
formalpara.para: &merge-pathnames; is used to specify default components for pathnames, so there is some analogy between (&merge-pathnames; a b) and (&or-m; a b). Obviously, putting in the same default a second time should do the same as putting it in once: (&or-m; a b b) is the same as (&or-m; a b), so (&merge-pathnames; (&merge-pathnames; a b) b) should be the same as (&merge-pathnames; a b).

section.para: (This question actually does matter because in &cl; there is no distinction between pathnames with defaults merged-in and pathnames with defaults not yet applied.)

Now, (&merge-pathnames; (&merge-pathnames; #P"x/" #P"y/") #P"y/") and (&merge-pathnames; #P"x/" #P"y/") are &equal; in &clisp; (when &pathmerge; is &nil;), but not in implementations that strictly follow the &ansi-cl; spec. In fact, the above twice-default = once-default rule holds for all pathnames in &clisp;.

formalpara.title: Rationale
formalpara.para: merge is merge and not or.

section.title: Function &load-logical-pathname-translations;
section.para:
When the &host-r; argument to &load-logical-pathname-translations; is not a defined logical host yet, we proceed as follows:
If both &env-var;s LOGICAL_HOST_&host-r;_FROM and LOGICAL_HOST_&host-r;_TO exist, then their values define the map of the &host-r;. If the &env-var; LOGICAL_HOST_&host-r; exists, its value is read from, and the result is passed to (&setf; &logical-pathname-translations;). Variable &load-lpt-db; is consulted. Its value should be a list of files and/or directories, which are searched for in the &load-paths;, just like for &load-my;. When the element is a file, it is &read; from, Allegro CL-style, odd objects being host names and even object being their &logical-pathname-translations;. When the element is a directory, a file, named &host-r; or &host-r;.host, in that directory, is &read; from once, CMUCL-style, the object read being the &logical-pathname-translations; of the &host-r;.

section.title: Function &absolute-pathname;
section.para: (&absolute-pathname; &path-r;) converts the &path-r; to a physical pathname, then - if its directory component is not absolute - converts it to an absolute pathname, by merging in the current process' directory. This is like &truename;, except that it does not verify that a file named by the &path-r; exists, not even that its directory exists. It does no filesystem accesses, except to determine the current directory. This function is useful when you want to save a pathname over time, or pass a pathname to an external program.

simplesect.title: Function &probe-file;
simplesect.para: &probe-file; cannot be used to check whether a directory exists. Use functions &probe-dir; or &directory; for this.

simplesect.title: Function &file-author;
simplesect.para: &file-author; always returns &nil;, because the operating systems &clisp; is ported to do not store a file's author in the file system. Some operating systems, such as &unix;, have the notion of a file's owner, and some other &cl; implementations return the user name of the file owner. &clisp; does not do this, because owner and author are not the same; in particular, authorship is preserved by copying, while ownership is not.
Use OS:FILE-OWNER to find the owner of the file.

simplesect.title: Function &probe-dir;
simplesect.para: (&probe-dir; &path-r;) tests whether &path-r; exists and is a directory. It will, unlike &probe-file; or &truename;, not &signal; an &error-t; if the parent directory of &path-r; does not exist.

simplesect.title: Function &delete-file;
simplesect.para: (&delete-file; &path-r;) deletes the pathname &path-r;, not its &truename;, and returns the absolute pathname it actually removed or &nil; if &path-r; did not exist. When &path-r; points to a file which is currently open in &clisp;, an &err-sig;.

simplesect.title: Function &directory;
simplesect.para:
(&directory; &optional-amp; &path-r; &key-amp; :FULL :CIRCLE &if-does-not-exist;) can run in two modes:
If &path-r; contains no name or type component, a list of all matching directories is produced. E.g., (&directory; "/etc/*/") lists all subdirectories in the directory #P"/etc/". Otherwise a list of all matching files is returned. E.g., (&directory; "/etc/*") lists all regular files in the directory #P"/etc/". If the :FULL argument is non-&nil;, additional information is returned: for each matching file you get a &list-t; of at least four elements (file-pathname file-truename file-write-date-as-decoded-time file-length).
If you want all the files &and-e; subdirectories in the current directory, you should use (&nconc; (&directory; "*/") (&directory; "*")). If you want all the files and subdirectories in all the subdirectories under the current directory (similar to the ls -R &unix; command), use (&nconc; (&directory; "**/") (&directory; "**/*")).
&unix-only; If the :CIRCLE argument is non-&nil;, the function avoids endless loops that may result from symbolic links.
The argument &if-does-not-exist; controls the treatment of links pointing to non-existent files and can take the following values:
:DISCARD (default) discard the bad directory entries
&error-k; an &err-sig; on bad directory entries (this corresponds to the default behavior of &directory; in &cmucl;)
:KEEP keep bad directory entries in the returned list (this roughly corresponds to the (&directory; ... :TRUNAMEP &nil;) call in &cmucl;)
:IGNORE Similar to :DISCARD, but also do not signal an error when a directory is unaccessible (contrary to the &ansi-cl; specification).

simplesect.title: Function EXT:DIR
simplesect.para: (EXT:DIR &optional-amp; &path-r;) is like &directory;, but displays the pathnames instead of returning them. (EXT:DIR) shows the contents of the current directory.

simplesect.title: Function &cd;
simplesect.para:
(&cd; &path-r;) sets it, (&cd;) returns it.
&unix-only; (&cd; [&path-r;]) manages the current directory.
&win32-only; (&cd; [&path-r;]) manages the current device and the current directory.

simplesect.title: Function EXT:DEFAULT-DIRECTORY
simplesect.para: (EXT:DEFAULT-DIRECTORY) is equivalent to (&cd;). (&setf; (EXT:DEFAULT-DIRECTORY) &path-r;) is equivalent to (&cd; &path-r;), except for the return value.

section.title: Interactive Streams [CLHS-21.1.1.1.3]
section.para: Interactive streams are those whose next input might depend on a prompt one might output.

section.title: Terminal interaction
section.para: See also .

section.title: Command line editing with &readline;

subtitle.emphasis: Only in &clisp; linked against the &readline; library.

section.para: Input through &terminal-io-var; uses the &readline; library. Arrow keys can be used to move within the input history. The #\Tab key completes the &symbol-t; name or &pathname-t; that is being typed. See readline user manual for general details and for &clisp;-specific extensions.

warning.simpara: The &readline; library is &not-e; used (even when &clisp; is linked against it) if the standard and standard output do not both refer to the same terminal. This is determined by the function stdio_same_tty_p in file src/stream.d. In some exotic cases, e.g., when running under &gdb; in an rxvt window under &cygwin;, this may be determined incorrectly.

section.para: See also .

formalpara.title: Linking against &readline;
formalpara.para:
For &clisp; to use &readline; it has to be detected by the configure process. If you run it as ./configure --with-readline, it will fail if it cannot find a modern working &readline; installation. If you use the option --without-readline, it will not even try to find &readline;. The default behavior (--with-readline=default) is to use &readline; if it is found and link &clisp; without it otherwise.
You can find out whether &readline; has been detected by running &sh-prompt; grep HAVE_READLINE unixconf.h in your build directory.

section.title: Macro &with-kbd;
section.subtitle: &unix-w32-only;
section.para:
&terminal-io-var; is not the only stream that communicates directly with the user: During execution of the body of a (&with-kbd; . &body-r;) form, &kbd-in; is the &stream-t; that reads the keystrokes from the keyboard. It returns every keystroke in detail as an &input-char; with the following slots (see for accessing them):
&ch-r; the &character-t; for standard keys (accessed with &character;)
For non-standard keys &character; &sig-err;, use &char-key;:
(&with-kbd; (&loop; :for &ch-r; = (&read-char; &kbd-in;) :for &key-r; = (&or-m; (&char-key; &ch-r;) (&character; &ch-r;)) :do (&print; (&list; &ch-r; &key-r;)) :when (&eql; &key-r; #\Space) :return (&list; &ch-r; &key-r;)))
&key-r;
the key name, for non-standard keys (accessed with &char-key;):
&unix-w32-only;
&key-value-header;
F1..F12 :F1..:F12
Insert :INSERT
Delete :DELETE
Home :HOME
End :END
Center :CENTER
PgUp :PGUP
PgDn :PGDN
Arrow keys :LEFT :RIGHT :UP :DOWN
bits
:HYPER (&win32-only;) if a non-standard key. These keys are:
[&win32;]: Function keys, cursor keypads, numeric keypad.
:SUPER (&win32-only;) if pressed together with &shift; key(s) and if the keystroke would have been different without &shift;.
:CONTROL if pressed together with the &ctrl; key.
:META (&win32-only;) if pressed together with the &alt; key.
font Always &zero;.
This keyboard input is not echoed on the screen. During execution of a (&with-kbd; . &body-r;) form, no input from &terminal-io-var; or any synonymous stream should be requested.

warning.para: Since &input-char; is &not-e; a subtype of &character-t;, &read-line; on &kbd-in; is illegal.

section.title: Function &stream-element-type;
section.para: &stream-element-type; is &setf;able. The &stream-element-type; of &stream-t;s created by the functions &open;, &mk-pipe-in; &mk-pipe-out;, &mk-pipe-io;, &so-accept;, &so-connect; can be modified, if the old and the new &stream-element-type;s are either both equivalent to &character-t; or &ubyte-8; or &sbyte-8;; or both equivalent to &ubyte-n; or &sbyte-n;, with the same &n-r;.

section.title: Binary input from &standard-input-var;
section.para: Note that you cannot change &stream-element-type; for some built-in streams, such as terminal streams, which is normally the value of &terminal-io-var;. Since &standard-input-var; normally is a &synonym-stream-t; pointing to &terminal-io-var;, you cannot use &read-byte; in the it.

Since CGI (Common Gateway Interface) provides the form data for METHOD="POST" on the stdin, and the server will &not-e; send you an &eos; on the end of the data, you will need to use (&getenv; "CONTENT_LENGTH") to determine how much data you should read from stdin. &clisp; will detect that stdin is not a terminal and create a regular &file-stream-t; which can be passed to (&setf; &stream-element-type;). To test this functionality interactively, you will need to open the standard input in the binary mode:
(let ((buf (&make-array; (&parse-integer; (&getenv; "CONTENT_LENGTH")) :element-type '&ubyte-8;))) (&with-open-stream; (in (&make-stream; &input-k; &eltype; '&ubyte-8;)) (&read-sequence; buf in)) buf)
